Description: Hospital must notify BCBSA and the Local Plan within 24 hours (72 hours on weekends if no 24-hour access) of any material change affecting patient care.
This includes changes to the transplant program or services, such as suspension or cessation.
The notice must relate to the most recent Blue Quality Centers for Transplant credentialing process.
Hospital must ensure all Participating Physicians and Providers comply with the Agreement.
Written agreements (or arrangements acceptable to BCBSA) must be in place with Participating Physicians and Providers.
These agreements must require compliance with the terms of the Agreement for Transplant Services.
Hospital agrees to admit Members for Transplant Services only with written Preauthorization from the Referring Plan.
Hospital must inform BCBSA of Preauthorization within one week of admission or Preauthorization.
Referring Plan case managers must be notified of admission within one business day via telephone.
Hospital shall perform adult and/or pediatric, cadaveric and/or living donor transplants or retransplants.
Transplant Services are provided to Members with written Preauthorization from the Referring Plan.
Services include human organ and/or tissue transplants as applicable.
In emergency cases, Hospital must obtain Preauthorization from the Referring Plan prior to admission, unless it delays necessary treatment.
Preauthorization for Emergency Services may be obtained by telephone, with written confirmation to follow.
If Preauthorization cannot be obtained due to severity, Hospital must notify the Referring Plan no later than the first business day after admission.
Local Plan cannot retrospectively deny claims with Preauthorization unless abuse, fraud, or concealment of material information is demonstrated.
Referring Plans must also adhere to this rule, as required by state or federal law.
The Participating Hospital must have provided all necessary information during the Preauthorization review.
Referring Plan shall pay Hospital for Transplant Services as per Attachment A, without surcharges.
Payment is subject to benefit maximums, copayment, coinsurance, and deductible provisions of the Member Benefit Contract.
Hospital is responsible for compensating Participating Physicians and Providers, who cannot separately bill for Transplant Services.
Hospital shall only seek compensation from the Referring Plan for Transplant Services, even in cases of non-payment or insolvency.
Hospital cannot bill Members or others for services, except for applicable copayments, coinsurance, or deductibles.
This provision survives termination of the Agreement and supersedes any contrary agreements.
Members may request services not authorized by the Referring Plan or covered by the Member Benefit Contract.
Hospital must inform Members of their payment responsibility before rendering such services.
Participating Plans and BCBSA have no financial responsibility for non-covered services.
Hospital must follow the administrative policies of the Hospital Procedures Manual.
As a condition of payment, Hospital must certify in writing that all Established Charges have been bundled.
The manual may be amended from time to time and is incorporated by reference.
Referring Plan must process and pay Clean Claims within 45 days of receipt or request additional information.
If additional information is requested, payment must be made within 45 days of receiving the complete information.
Late payments incur interest at 1% above Bank One's prime rate, starting 45 days after receipt of Clean Claims or additional information.
Hospital must permit Referring Plan or BCBSA to conduct case audits with 14 days' prior written notice.
Audits may include adherence to patient selection criteria, quality of care, and follow-up care.
Audits are for payment and health care operations as defined in the Privacy Standards.
Hospital must provide a written protocol for discharge planning and follow-up care for Members receiving Transplant Services.
The protocol must be approved by the Referring Plan or BCBSA before discharge.
Hospital must provide Protected Health Information to Referring Plan or BCBSA for Preauthorization, discharge planning, and care coordination.
Parties must obtain assurances from third parties that Protected Health Information will not be used or disclosed improperly.
Third parties must use safeguards to prevent unauthorized use or disclosure of Protected Health Information.
Third parties must notify the parties immediately of any breaches of confidentiality.
